beats.reasoning: The first beat marks the start of the intro where the designer needs to establish a subtle, cool atmosphere. With medium energy but no build-up yet, keeping this beat empty preserves breathing room and follows the 60‑70% sync rule, letting later beats in the intro gradually add motion and color.

This is an early intro beat with low energy and dominant high frequency, but it's the off‑beat (beat 2). Following the 60‑70% sync rule and the need for breathing room at the start, we leave this beat empty to build tension gradually.

At ~1% the track is still in the intro phase, which should be subtle and build tension gradually. Beat 3 is early and we aim for 60‑70% sync, so leaving it empty provides breathing room and avoids an overly busy start.

At ~1% of the track this is an intro beat with low energy and high dominant band. Intro should stay dark and subtle, building tension; adding motion or VFX would violate the rule to keep calm sections minimal.

Beat 5/248 falls in the early intro section (~2% of the track) with low energy and no build‑up cues. Following professional rules, the intro should use subtle, cool washes and leave most beats empty to create breathing room and gradual tension. Therefore no active lighting effects are warranted here.
Low energy, high‑band intro beat with vocals and no dramatic build‑up; following the 60‑70% sync rule and intro guidelines, this beat remains breathing room to allow tension to grow.

Beat 7/248 falls in the very early intro, low energy, and the rule of 60‑70% sync suggests breathing room here. No dramatic motion or VFX is appropriate at this point, so we keep the lights off for contrast and build tension.

Beat 8/248 falls in the intro where the energy is low and the focus is on subtle buildup; professional practice dictates minimal or no active effects to preserve a calm atmosphere and avoid premature strobe or VFX. Following the 60‑70% sync rule, this beat serves as breathing room, so no effects are activated.

Beat 9 falls in the intro where the energy is low and the section is meant to build tension quietly. Keeping this beat empty provides breathing room and follows the intro guidelines of subtle, cool lighting without strobe or VFX.

Beat 10/248 falls in the very early intro (~4% of the track) with low energy and a high‑band focus; professional practice suggests keeping the stage dark and subtle at this point to build tension, so no effects are used here for breathing room.

Intro section with medium energy and high dominant, we give a subtle wave motion on a single moving head to build tension while keeping colors cool and intensity moderate. This beat is part of the 60‑70% sync rule, providing breathing space elsewhere.

Beat 12/248 is still in the intro, with low energy and high‑band dominance; professional convention calls for a dark, subtle wash to build tension. To give the audience breathing room and avoid an over‑busy opening, we leave this beat empty.

Beat 13/248 falls in the intro, with low energy and no dramatic cue. Intro sections should stay subtle and build tension gradually, so we leave this beat empty to provide breathing room while preserving contrast for later beats.

Beat 14 sits in the early intro where the track is building tension but not yet dropping. The medium energy and high‑frequency dominance suggest a gentle rotational motion to hint at the upcoming build, while keeping the lights subtle to preserve the intro’s calm atmosphere. A single moving head with a modest rotate, warm static color, and mild intensity ping‑pong provides a tasteful cue without overwhelming the section.
Beat 15/248 falls in the intro, low energy with no key lyric cue. Following the 60–70% sync rule and intro guidelines, this beat should remain silent to build tension and provide breathing room.
Beat 16 is in the intro, low energy and still building tension. To adhere to the 60‑70% sync rule and avoid over‑dramatic lighting early, this beat is kept silent for breathing room.

Beat 17 falls early in the intro, where the energy is moderate but still building tension. A single moving head with a gentle wave motion provides subtle movement to support the vocals without overwhelming the calm atmosphere, following the 60–70% sync rule and avoiding strobe or heavy VFX at this stage.

Beat 18 sits in the intro where the energy is medium but the overall mood is still building; a gentle wave motion on a single moving head provides subtle motion without overwhelming the calm atmosphere, following the 60‑70% sync rule and keeping the intro restrained.

Beat 19 sits in the opening 7 % of the track, still in the intro phase where the energy is only medium and the lyric line repeats. To build tension without overwhelming the vocals, a subtle rotating single‑head light is ideal, providing gentle motion and a cool wash while keeping the stage readable.

At 8% of the track this is early intro with low energy and no build‑up; the professional rule is to keep the opening calm and not trigger VFX or loud motion. Therefore this beat remains breathing room, no effects.

Beat 21 is in the early intro (≈8% of the track) with medium, low‑energy, mid‑band emphasis and no VFX cues. To maintain subtle tension, a slow rotating single light with a static cool color and modest intensity variation is appropriate, keeping the beat breathing room while still giving a slight motion cue.

At 9% into the track, the intro is still building tension. Although the beat registers high energy, professional rules advise keeping the light design subtle—no VFX or strobe, just a gentle laser fan in a cool wash to support the vocal line.

At ~9% of the track the intro is building tension; high energy is present but we keep visual intensity low to avoid overwhelming the vocals. A subtle rotating single head (Motion 4) with a warm static color and gentle ping‑pong intensity creates motion without full‑scale beam arrays, following the 60‑70% sync rule and intro restraint.

At ~9% of the track the intro is still building tension; we add a subtle single‑head wave to start the energy without overwhelming. This keeps the intro dark and supportive of vocals while following the 60‑70% sync rule.

At beat 25/248 (~10% of the track) we’re still in the intro phase, so we keep the lighting subtle. The high energy cue calls for a gentle motion, but VFX are reserved for drops—hence a low‑intensity laser fan with a static cool color and a ping‑pong intensity creates tension without overwhelming the vocals.

Beat 26/248 falls in the early verse where the energy is high but the arrangement is still supportive of vocals; a gentle moving-head wave keeps the groove without over‑stimulation. Following the 60‑70% sync rule, a single light group with a subtle Wave motion and ping‑pong intensity gives breathing room while maintaining contrast, and the static warm color complements the vocal line.

This verse beat has high energy but is not a drop or climax, so we keep it subtle and use a single moving head to support the vocals. A Wave motion (MotionEffect 3) with a warm static color and spectrum‑based intensity gives energy without overwhelming the section.

Beat 28 falls early in the verse (~11% of the track) yet the energy spikes high with a dominant high-frequency mix and vocal line present. To support the vocals without turning the section into a full drop, a multi‑light laser cone with subtle color variation and wave‑style intensity keeps the feel lively yet restrained. This follows the 60‑70% sync rule and avoids aggressive VFX during a non‑climactic part.

Beat 29 falls in the early verse where the energy is high but the section should remain supportive of vocals. A subtle rotating single‑head light with a warm static color and gentle ping‑pong intensity provides motion without overwhelming the mix, aligning with the 60‑70% sync rule and verse‑style restraint.
Verse section with high energy but still supportive. Use a rotating single head with ping‑pong color and intensity to provide motion without overwhelming vocals.

At ~12% of the track this is a high‑energy verse, so we use moderate motion without VFX. A single moving head provides a gentle wave to support the vocals, while a multi‑head laser fan adds subtle dynamic color. This keeps the 60‑70% sync rule and follows the verse‑supporting style.

Beat 32 falls in the verse section (~13% of the track), so we keep the lighting subtle to support vocals. The high energy and bass‑dominant cue suggests a gentle wave motion on a single moving head; a static warm color with ping‑pong intensity adds subtle movement without turning the verse into a full‑blown drop, aligning with the 60‑70% sync rule.

Beat 33 falls in a high‑energy verse; to support vocals without overpowering, a subtle rotating wash is chosen. The motion keeps the groove alive, while a warm static color and alternating intensity provide contrast, following professional rules for verse lighting.

Beat 34 sits in a high‑energy verse; we add a subtle laser beam and a moving‑head wave to support the vocals without turning the whole stage on. This keeps the 60‑70% sync rule, uses motion appropriate to the dominant high energy, and maintains contrast with the surrounding quieter beats.

Beat 35 falls on a downbeat in a high‑energy verse with vocal lyric; a laser cone provides a sharp, supportive cue while keeping the section subtle. This aligns with the 60‑70 % sync rule and the verse structure guidelines.

Beat 36/248 falls in the early verse with high energy and bass dominance; we avoid VFX here and use a gentle wave motion to accent the bass hits while keeping a warm static color to support vocals without overwhelming the mix. This provides a 60‑70% sync rate and maintains breathing room for later drops.

Beat 37 is early in the verse, high‑energy but still meant to support vocals rather than dominate; a subtle wave motion on a single moving head provides texture without overwhelming. Following the 60‑70% sync rule, this beat receives an effect to build intensity gradually.

Beat 38 falls in the early verse (~15% of the track). Though the energy is labeled high, verse sections should maintain a supportive, moderate presence. A single moving head with a gentle wave motion and warm static color keeps the vocals in focus without overwhelming the mix, complying with the 60‑70% sync rule and the professional rule to keep verse light subtle.

Beat 39 falls on a strong beat (beat 3) in a verse section (~15% of the track). High energy and vocal lyrics call for a subtle but supportive effect— a single laser cone with a warm wash keeps the vocals in focus without overwhelming the calm verse mood.

Beat 40 falls in the verse section with medium energy and high‑frequency emphasis; a subtle moving‑head wave with gentle color shifts provides vocal support without overpowering the track. This keeps the 60–70 % sync rule while maintaining contrast and breath space.

Beat 41 falls in the first verse but still has high energy and a dominant high frequency, so we use moderate motion to support vocals without turning the section into a full drop. A rotating single head keeps the focus on the singer, while a laser fan adds subtle beam movement; no VFX or strobe is used to preserve the verse’s supportive character. The effects are limited to two groups to keep a 60–70 % sync rate and provide breathing room elsewhere.

Beat 42 falls in a verse where the track is still high energy but vocals dominate; a subtle Wave motion on a single moving head keeps the groove without overwhelming the singers. A warm static color and spectrum‑based intensity support the vocal line while staying within the 60‑70% sync rule.

Beat 43/248 falls within the high‑energy chorus drop where vocals are loud and the bass drives the groove; professional rules call for full‑on effects on the drop, so we activate a VFX group for fireworks along with laser and motion beams to match the energy and sustain momentum.

Beat 44 sits in the middle of a verse with medium energy and a high‑frequency dominant, so we keep the lighting subtle yet supportive. A single laser cone on a multi‑light group provides a gentle visual cue without overwhelming the vocals, respecting the 60‑70% sync rule and the verse‑stage guidelines.

Beat 45 falls in the early verse with medium energy and high‑frequency emphasis. To support vocals without overpowering, a gentle rotating motion on a single moving head with a warm static color and subtle spectrum‑based intensity gives breathing room while staying in sync with the 60‑70% rule.

At beat 46/248 (≈18% of the song) the track is in a verse with high energy and a dominant high‑frequency line. Following the 60–70% sync rule and the verse‑support rule, a subtle wave motion on a single moving head is appropriate to accentuate the vocals without overwhelming the section.

Beat 47 falls in the middle of a high‑energy verse; although no lyric is detected, the high dominant‑high energy warrants a dynamic laser effect. Following the 60‑70% sync rule, we use a single multi‑light group to provide a driving beam without overwhelming the vocals.

Verse section with medium energy and high‑frequency dominant band; we use a gentle rotating beam to support vocals without overwhelming, keeping the look warm and neutral. This beat follows the 60‑70% sync rule and provides subtle motion while maintaining contrast with calmer sections.

Beat 49 falls in a high‑energy verse where vocal lines are prominent but still before the drop.  Following the 60‑70 % sync rule, we use a laser beam to accentuate the melody without a VFX burst, keeping the light dynamic yet balanced with the music.

At ~20% of the song, this is still a verse—supportive, not overwhelming. The high energy suggests a subtle motion to keep the beat alive, so we use a single moving head with a Wave motion, warm static color, and ping‑pong intensity for gentle build. No VFX or lasers, keeping the focus on vocals.

Beat 51 falls in the verse yet shows high energy and dominant high frequencies, so we add a subtle laser cone to support the vocal build without overwhelming the section. The static warm color and wave intensity sync with the bass, keeping the light breathing and in line with the 60‑70% sync rule.

Beat 52 falls in a verse with high energy but not a drop; to support vocals we use a subtle rotating wash rather than full lasers or VFX. One single-light group with a rotate motion, static warm color, and alternating intensity keeps the beat occupied while preserving breathing room per the 60‑70% sync rule.

Beat 53 falls in the verse section (~21% of the track). The energy is high but the structure calls for supportive, not overwhelming effects, so a single moving‑head with a gentle wave motion and a warm static color provides vocal support while keeping the intensity balanced.

Beat 54 falls in a mid‑verse where energy is high but not at a drop or chorus. To support the vocals without overpowering, we use a subtle rotating single moving head with a warm static wash and gentle wave‑intensity modulation, keeping the overall impact restrained as per the 60‑70% sync rule.

Beat 55 falls in a verse with medium energy and high dominant band; a subtle wave motion on a single moving head keeps the light visible but not overwhelming, supporting the vocal line while following the 60‑70% sync rule.

Beat 56 falls on a high‑energy drop with the hook lyric “Turn down for what”; professional rule 3 calls for dramatic effects on key moments. A multi‑light LaserCone with dynamic color and wave‑intensity syncs to the bass and keeps the energy high while staying within the 60‑70 % sync guideline.

Beat 57/248 falls within a high‑energy chorus with strong vocal lines. To accentuate the build‑up, a multi‑light group with a LaserCone offers a sweeping beam effect, while RandomPerBeam colors and WaveIntensity create dynamic motion that syncs with the beat. This keeps the 60‑70% sync rule while adding the excitement needed for the chorus peak.

Beat 58 falls in a high‑energy verse with vocal lyrics; professional practice calls for supportive motion without full‑on strobe. A gentle wave on a single head plus a synchronized laser fan gives contrast and energy while keeping the focus on the vocals.

Beat 59 is right before the drop, still high energy with vocal lyrics. Using a laser cone and a moving head wave builds tension without full-on frenzy, following the 60‑70% sync rule and verse‑build‑up guidelines.

Beat 60 occurs in a high‑energy verse; we add a moderate amount of movement to support the vocals without overwhelming the section. Two synchronized effects provide rhythm and color while keeping 30–40% breathing room.

Beat 61 is a downbeat in a moderate‑energy verse with vocals; it should feel strong yet not overpowering. A wave motion on a single moving head (group 2) gives a supportive wash, while a subtle laser cone (group 4) adds a touch of visual interest. This keeps sync at ~65% while respecting the verse‑supporting palette.
Beat 62 falls in a low‑energy verse section with no dramatic lyric change; keeping it empty provides breathing room per the 60‑70% sync rule and avoids over‑stimulation.

Beat 63 falls in the verse where vocals are present but energy is still moderate; we keep effects subtle yet supportive. A single moving head with a gentle rotate motion and a warm static color provides a wash without overpowering the vocal line, following the 60‑70% sync rule.

Beat 64 falls in the mid‑verse where the energy is high but the section should remain supportive rather than overwhelming. A single subtle laser fan with a warm static color and moderate intensity provides a gentle wash that follows the 60‑70% sync rule and keeps the focus on the vocals.

Beat 65 sits early in the verse with high energy and vocals; to keep the groove without overwhelming, a gentle Wave motion on a single moving head supports the vocal line. A warm static color and ping‑pong intensity add subtle dynamics, while the rest of the beat stays quiet for breathing room.

Beat 66 falls in the verse where the energy is medium and the focus is on supporting vocals. To avoid a robotic feel and respect the 60‑70% sync rule, a single moving head with a gentle Wave motion and warm static color provides subtle support without overwhelming the mix. Beat 67 sits in a low‑energy verse with no major cues; leaving it silent preserves breathing room per the 60–70% sync rule and keeps the lighting subtle for the vocal support.

Beat 68 is a downbeat in the verse with low energy; professional convention calls for subtle or no effects to support vocals without overwhelming. Following the 60‑70% sync rule, this beat can remain breathing room while prior beats already provide motion.

Beat 69 falls within the early verse, low energy and high dominant band; professional practice calls for minimal or no lighting to support vocals without overwhelming. Keeping this beat silent provides breathing room and follows the 60–70% sync rule while avoiding unnecessary effects during calm sections.

Beat 70/248 falls in a low‑energy verse section (~28% of the track). To support the vocals without overwhelming, a gentle moving‑head wash with subtle intensity variation is appropriate, following the 60–70% sync rule for breathing room.

Beat 71 falls in a low‑energy verse section, so following the 60‑70% sync rule we give breathing room and avoid any dramatic motion or VFX. This keeps the focus on vocals without overstimulating the audience.

Beat 72 falls in a low‑energy verse section; professional practice suggests minimal or no effects to support vocals without overwhelming. To keep the 60–70% sync rule and preserve breathing room, this beat is left empty.

Beat 73/248 is in a low‑energy verse; to keep the arrangement breathing and avoid over‑stimulation, this beat is left empty per the 60‑70% sync rule and the rule against heavy motion in calm sections.

Beat 74 falls in the early verse (≈30% of the track) with medium energy and vocal presence; we use a gentle wave on a single moving head and a subtle laser cone to add motion without overpowering the vocals. Both groups employ a warm static color and a ping‑pong intensity effect for mild variation while keeping the overall atmosphere supportive and restrained.

Beat 75 falls in a low‑energy verse section (~30% of the track) with no lyrical or dynamic cue for a dramatic change. Following the 60‑70% sync rule and the rule to reserve VFX for drops, this beat serves as breathing room and should remain silent.

Beat 76/248 falls in a low‑energy pre‑chorus build‑up with only moderate brightness and no lyric change; keeping it empty gives breathing room and follows the 60‑70% sync rule while preventing premature intensity spikes.

Beat 77 falls in the pre‑chorus build‑up where energy is rising and high‑frequency elements are present. To gradually increase intensity, a laser cone from a multi‑light group is appropriate, with color and intensity cycling to keep the look dynamic without overwhelming the vocals.

Beat 78 falls in the pre‑chorus build‑up with low energy and high‑frequency vocals. To maintain breathing room and follow the 60‑70% sync rule, a single moving‑head light with a gentle Wave motion adds subtle movement without overpowering the vocal line, supporting the build without triggering VFX or intense lasers.

Beat 79/248 falls in a low‑energy pre‑chorus build‑up. Professional convention calls for breathing room during calm moments, so this beat remains silent to allow the next high‑energy beat to stand out.

Beat 80 falls in a pre‑chorus build‑up with medium energy and high‑frequency content, so we trigger gradual motion and color changes to raise intensity without a full drop. No VFX are used, keeping the build subtle and compliant with the drop‑only rule.

Beat 81/248 falls in a pre‑chorus build‑up with low energy and vocal lyrics; a subtle moving head can support the vocals without overwhelming. A single light group using a mild Wave motion with a steady color and ping‑pong intensity keeps the rhythm alive while maintaining the 60‑70% sync rule.

Beat 82 falls in the pre‑chorus build‑up with low energy and moderate brightness; to maintain the 60‑70% sync rule and allow gradual intensity rise, this beat provides breathing room rather than new effects.

At ~33% of the track the energy is medium with a high‑frequency dominant sound and vocals, signalling a pre‑chorus build‑up. A LaserFan with random colors and alternating beam intensity gives rising intensity without overwhelming the vocals, following the 60‑70% sync rule.

Beat 84 falls in the pre‑chorus build‑up with medium energy and a high‑frequency dominant band—ideal for subtle motion and color changes that ramp intensity without full VFX. A LaserCone on a multi‑light group adds bright beam movement, while a Wave on a single light provides rhythmic motion; both use color and intensity effects to support vocals and build momentum.

Beat 85 falls in the pre‑chorus build‑up with medium energy and high‑band dominance; the lyric line gives a cue to support vocals without overpowering. Following the 60‑70% sync rule, we add a gentle wave motion on a single light group and a subtle laser cone on a multi‑light group to gradually ramp intensity while keeping the section restrained.

Beat 86 falls in the pre‑chorus build‑up with medium energy and high‑frequency vocals, so a subtle yet escalating effect is appropriate. A LaserFan on the multi‑light group syncs with the melodic line, while random colors and ping‑pong intensity add dynamic contrast without overwhelming the vocals.

Beat 87 sits in the pre‑chorus build‑up phase; energy is still low but the following beats ramp up. To create a sense of gradual motion without overpowering, a subtle rotate on a single moving head is appropriate, giving the audience a visual cue that the intensity is rising.

Beat 88/248 sits in the pre‑chorus build‑up with medium energy and a high‑frequency dominant band, so we introduce moderate motion and lasers to signal an impending drop while leaving room for the following high‑energy beats. A wave on a single moving head keeps the texture subtle yet engaging, and laser cone/fan on multi‑light groups add forward momentum without overwhelming the vocals.

Beat 89/248 falls in the pre‑chorus build‑up, high energy and dominant high‑frequency content. We add a LaserCone on a multi‑light group with dynamic colors and wave‑intensity to raise tension while keeping VFX off until the drop. This follows the 60‑70% sync rule and the gradual build‑up convention.

Beat 90/248 falls in the pre‑chorus build‑up (~36% of the track) with high energy and a high‑dominant band.  According to professional rules this is a moment for gradual intensification, so we enable a laser cone to hint at the upcoming drop and a wave motion on a moving head to keep the vocals supported, but keep VFX off to avoid drama before the chorus.

Beat 91 sits in the pre‑chorus build‑up where energy is high but VFX are still reserved for the drop. A laser fan on a multi‑light group creates a rising intensity, while a rotating single light adds motion without overwhelming the vocals. Both groups are synced to the beat, keeping the 60‑70% sync rule and offering contrast before the full chorus.

Beat 92/248 falls in a high‑energy build‑up with bass dominance, signaling a gradual lift toward the drop. To support the vocal intensity without overwhelming, a single rotating moving head (Wave/Rotate) with dynamic color and intensity variations provides movement and contrast, following the 60‑70% sync rule.

Beat 93 sits in the build‑up with high energy and dominant high‑frequency content; professional practice calls for lasers to heighten the rising intensity. A multi‑light LaserCone with random colors and alternating intensity keeps the motion dynamic while avoiding strobe fatigue.

Beat 94 falls in the pre‑chorus build‑up with high energy and dominant high frequencies; we increase intensity with coordinated laser beams and gentle wave motion, but keep it light enough to avoid full drop saturation. This provides a rising dynamic cue while preserving breathing room for subsequent beats.

Beat 95 falls into the build‑up phase just before the drop; energy is high but still a pre‑chorus, so VFX is off and we focus on progressive motion and color to heighten anticipation. The selected groups use lasers and rotating/wave motions to sync with the high‑frequency melody while keeping 60‑70% of beats active for breathing room.

Beat 96/248 falls in the pre‑chorus build‑up; high energy and high‑frequency content call for a moderate increase in motion while keeping VFX reserved for the drop. A wave on the single moving head provides rhythmic motion, and a laser cone adds forward thrust to the rising intensity, both synced to the beat without strobing.

Beat 97 falls in the pre‑chorus build‑up with continuous high energy and a high‑frequency dominant band.  To keep the momentum rising without reaching a drop, we add synchronized laser motion (LaserCone) and a wave‑style moving head, using color and intensity variations to support the vocals. No VFX are used, as the climax has not yet arrived.

Beat 98/248 sits in the pre‑chorus build‑up with high energy and dominant high frequencies, so we cue a gradual increase in visual intensity. Two synchronized effects—LaserFan on the multi‑light group and Wave motion on a single moving head—provide motion and color support for the vocal line while keeping the energy controlled before the drop.

At beat 99/248 the track is still in the pre‑chorus build‑up, so we introduce subtle yet progressive motion while keeping the energy ascending. A laser cone on the multi‑light group provides a sweeping visual cue, while a rotating single head adds rhythmic movement to support the vocal line.

Beat 100/248 falls in the pre‑chorus build‑up; the track is high energy with dominant high frequencies and repeating vocal lines, so we add synchronized laser motion to build intensity while keeping a single‑head motion to support the vocal swell. This keeps the sync rate around 60‑70% and follows the rule to avoid VFX outside the drop.

Beat 101 sits in the pre‑chorus build‑up with consistently high energy and dominant high‑frequency content; we want to ramp intensity without full drop. Lasers (multi‑light group) sync with the high‑energy melodic line while a single moving head adds a wave motion to support the bass hits. This keeps the 60‑70% sync rule while gradually increasing the visual impact.

Beat 102/248 sits in the pre‑chorus build‑up with high bass energy and vocal lyric, so we add a moderate amount of motion and laser to raise intensity without overwhelming. A single‑head wave syncs with the bass, while a laser cone adds visual depth for the approaching chorus.

At ~41% of the track this beat sits in the pre‑chorus build‑up. Energy is high and the hook repeats, so a subtle but escalating laser effect keeps the crowd engaged without the full drop intensity. A single laser cone with random colors and alternating intensity provides motion while leaving room for the upcoming chorus.

At beat 104/248 the track is in a high‑energy pre‑chorus build‑up with dominant high frequencies, so we add laser and moving‑head motion to ramp intensity without full VFX. A mix of a LaserCone, a LaserFan, and a single‑head wave provides 60‑70% sync while keeping contrast and breathing room for the following beats.

At beat 105/248 the track is in a high‑energy pre‑chorus build‑up; we want to ramp intensity without a full drop. Using a rotating single head (Wave/Rotate) and a laser cone on the multi‑light array gives motion and color contrast while keeping the beat from feeling over‑crowded.

This beat sits in the pre‑chorus build‑up at ~43% of the track, high energy and mid‑band dominance. Following the 60‑70% sync rule and avoiding VFX until the drop, a laser fan from a multi‑light group provides escalating intensity that supports the vocal line without overwhelming it.

Beat 107 falls in the pre‑chorus build‑up with high energy and dominant high frequencies, ideal for a laser effect that ramps intensity toward the drop. No VFX are used because VFX should be reserved for the drop/chorus; a single laser cone provides motion and visual interest while keeping the palette calm for the vocals.

At beat 108/248 (~43% of the track) the song is in a pre‑chorus build‑up with high energy and vocal presence. Following professional practice we add motion and color to support the vocals without full drop intensity, using rotating single lights and lasers to gradually ramp up momentum for the upcoming chorus.

Beat 109/248 falls in the pre‑chorus build‑up, high energy and high‑frequency vocals. To support the rising intensity without overwhelming, we use synchronized lasers (multi‑light group) and a single moving head that adds beat‑matching motion. This keeps the 60‑70% sync rule, adds contrast, and respects the VFX restriction for drops only.

Beat 110 falls in the pre‑chorus build‑up; energy is high yet still rising toward the drop. A steady LaserFan on the multi‑light group adds a growing beam effect, while a Wave motion on a single moving head injects rhythmic movement. Both use static warm color and spectrum‑based intensity to sync with the track without excessive strobing.

During the pre‑chorus build‑up at ~45% of the track, the energy is high and the beat lands on the downbeat. To increase intensity without overwhelming the vocals, a single laser cone effect with randomized colors and ping‑pong intensity provides a dramatic lift while respecting the 60‑70% sync rule.

Beat 112 is downbeat in the pre‑chorus build‑up; a stronger yet not full‑drop effect is appropriate. A single multi‑light group (LaserCone) with a warm static color and wave‑intensity will gradually raise energy while keeping the section supportive, not overwhelming the vocals.

Beat 113 falls within the sustained high‑energy chorus/drop. To maintain 60‑70% sync while keeping a dramatic build, we add a VFX burst and laser/beam motion synchronized with the bass and vocal hook. The medium energy rating still supports a full effect set without overwhelming the mix.

Beat 114/248 sits squarely in the chorus/drop with sustained high energy and prominent high‑frequency hits. Following professional conventions, we activate a simultaneous VFX burst for the dramatic impact, couple it with synchronized laser cones for the bright high‑band content, and add rotating single‑head movements to support the vocal and rhythmic drive while keeping breathing room for the next beat.

Beat 115/248 sits in a high‑energy chorus/drop with no lyric cue, so it should be a strong visual moment. We use lasers for fast motion (LaserCone) with dynamic random colors and alternating beam intensity, and add a simultaneous VFX burst to emphasize the peak. This follows the 60‑70% sync rule and keeps the show dramatic yet not over‑cluttered.

Beat 116/248 sits in a high‑energy chorus/drop with dominant high frequencies and vocal emphasis. Following professional rules we trigger a simultaneous VFX burst for drama, synchronized laser cone beams to match the high‑frequency melody, and rotating single‑head lights to accent the bass hits, providing a full‑on, visually cohesive impact.

Beat 117/248 falls in the chorus/drop section (~47% of the track) with high energy and dominant high‑frequency content. Following professional rules, we introduce dramatic VFX and synchronized laser beams while keeping breathing room by activating only a subset of the available groups.

Beat 118/248 falls within the peak chorus/drop, high energy and dominant high-frequency sounds. Following professional rules we add a VFX group for the dramatic drop, synchronized laser cones/fans for the melodic line, and moving head waves/rotations to follow the bass hits, while keeping 60‑70% of beats active. This balances impact and breathing room.

Beat 119/248 falls in the chorus drop, high‑energy, high‑frequency section with no lyrics, making it an ideal moment for a full visual climax. We combine simultaneous VFX, laser cones, and wave motion to maximize impact while respecting the 60‑70% sync rule and keeping the lighting dynamic yet coherent.

At beat 120/248 the track is in a high‑energy chorus drop (48% of the song). Professional practice calls for dramatic VFX and laser beams at this peak, but we maintain breathing room by using only three of five possible groups (≈60% sync).

Beat 121/248 sits in the chorus drop with high energy, dominant high frequencies, and vocal lyric content; it is an ideal moment for a dramatic multi‑layered lighting cue. We combine a laser cone on the multi‑light group, a rotating wave on a single light to accent the vocal line, and a VFX simultaneous burst to emphasize the drop, while keeping breathing room on other beats.

Beat 122/248 falls in the chorus/drop phase with high energy and no lyrics, so we can safely employ a full light assault. A simultaneous VFX group creates a dramatic backdrop, while a single moving head provides a rotating wash and ping‑pong intensity to accent the vocal delivery. A multi‑light laser cone with random per‑beam colors and wave intensity syncs with the high‑frequency melodic line for maximum visual impact.

Beat 123/248 falls in the mid‑chorus where energy is still high but not peak; a subtle laser fan keeps the visual momentum without overloading the mix. Using RandomPerBeam and AlternatingBeams adds variety, and no VFX is used to avoid cluttering the already intense drop.

Beat 124/248 sits in the mid‑song chorus drop – high energy, dominant high frequencies, lyrics present – so we trigger a full set of synchronized effects. A VFX group adds a simultaneous burst, while a LaserCone and a rotating single‑head provide bright, rhythmic motion that syncs with the bass and vocal peaks.
